item.title: Ukraine Routs Russian Forces in Northeast, Forcing a Retreat
item.description: Russia acknowledged that it had lost nearly all of the northern region of Kharkiv after a blitzkrieg thrust by Ukrainian fighters.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Juan Barreto/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Kharkiv region this weekend after Russian forces retreated.

item.title: Russia’s Retreat in Ukraine Pokes Holes in Putin’s Projection of Force
item.description: Russia’s military setbacks may be weakening President Vladimir V. Putin’s reputation at home as a savvy geopolitical strategist.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Juan Barreto/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The scene in the Kharkiv region this weekend after Russian forces retreated.

item.title: Expanded Safety Net Drives Sharp Drop in Child Poverty
item.description: With little public notice and accelerating speed, child poverty fell by 59 percent from 1993 to 2019, according to a comprehensive new analysis that shows the critical role of increased government aid.
item.dc:creator: Jason DeParle and Maddie McGarvey

item.title: With Queen Gone, Former Colonies Find a Moment to Rethink Lasting Ties
item.description: In Commonwealth nations with British colonial histories, Queen Elizabeth’s death is rekindling discussions about a more independent future.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Tim Graham Photo Library via Getty Images
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II in Tuvalu during a 1982 tour of the South Pacific, which also included a stop in the Solomon Islands.

item.title: What Will Happen to Queen Elizabeth’s Corgis
item.description: Prince Andrew, who had given his mother the two corgis she owned at her death, and his ex-wife, Sarah, Duchess of York, will care for the beloved pets.
item.dc:creator: Yonette Joseph
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: John Rider/Associated Press
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II owned more than 30 dogs during her reign, but was particularly fond of corgis, like these two she walked in London in 1970.

item.title: Queen’s Ties to Scotland Add New Wrinkle to Push for Independence
item.description: Political analysts said that respect for the queen and her devotion to Scotland could strengthen a union that has been under acute strain for more than a decade.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Oli Scarff/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Watching the hearse carrying the coffin of Queen Elizabeth II, draped in the Royal Standard of Scotland, in Edinburgh on Sunday.

item.title: In Hasidic Enclaves, Failing Yeshivas Flush With Public Money
item.description: New York’s Hasidic Jewish religious schools have benefited from $1 billion in government funding in the last four years but are unaccountable to outside oversight.
item.dc:creator: Eliza Shapiro, Brian M. Rosenthal and Jonah Markowitz
item.media:credit: Jonah Markowitz for The New York Times

item.title: NY State Vote Could Raise Pressure on Officials Over Hasidic Schools
item.description: Amid calls for intervention, the state Board of Regents is set to vote this week on new rules for holding private schools to minimum academic standards.
item.dc:creator: Eliza Shapiro and Brian M. Rosenthal
item.media:credit: Jonah Markowitz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Boys who attend private Hasidic religious schools are suffering from levels of educational deprivation that occur nowhere else in New York, a Times investigation found.

item.title: חסידישע מוסדות געבן נישט קיין עדיוקעשאן, אבער באקומען א שפע פון רעגירונגס געלטער
item.description: די חסידישע מוסדות אין ניו יארק האבן גענאסן פון 1 ביליאן דאלאר אין רעגירונגס געלטער דורכאויס די לעצטע פיר יאר אבער מוזן קיינעם נישט אפגעבן קיין דין וחשבון וואס מען לערנט ביי זיי
item.dc:creator: Eliza Shapiro, Brian M. Rosenthal and Jonah Markowitz
item.media:credit: Jonah Markowitz for The New York Times

item.title: Share Your Stories About Hasidic Schools
item.description: The New York Times is researching Hasidic yeshivas. Tell us about your experiences.
item.media:credit: Jonah Markowitz for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Central United Talmudical Academy spans an entire city block in Williamsburg. All its students who took state tests in 2019 failed. At a public school three blocks away, John Wayne Elementary, more than half of students passed.

item.title: So You Wanted to Get Work Done at the Office?
item.description: Some are nostalgic for the silence they had at home, especially since in-office perks, aimed at luring people back, can make it harder to concentrate.
item.dc:creator: Emma Goldberg
item.media:credit: Lily Padula

item.title: Carlos Alcaraz Wins US Open Men’s Singles Title, and Becomes No. 1
item.description: Alcaraz, the 19-year-old Spanish sensation, beat Casper Ruud of Norway in four sets to capture his first Grand Slam championship and take the top spot in the ATP world rankings.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Futterman
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: Carlos Alcaraz, 19, became the youngest man to win a Grand Slam title since Rafael Nadal in 2005.

item.title: On the Quiet Hardcourts in Spain, Carlos Alcaraz’s Star Was Already Shining
item.description: No matter how clear the potential, you never truly know what a tennis player is capable of until they have to fight for the biggest points on the biggest occasions.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Clarey
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Carlos Alcaraz beat Casper Rudd in four sets to win the U.S. Open men’s singles title Sunday.

item.title: How Book Bans Turned a Texas Town Upside Down
item.description: In a political environment where book-banning efforts are being used to drive voter sentiment, librarians find themselves on the front lines.
item.dc:creator: Erika Hayasaki

item.title: Marking 9/11, Biden Remembers the ‘Precious Lives Stolen From Us’
item.description: Members of the Biden administration honored the victims of the attacks, which, 21 years later, remain deeply painful for the family members who lost loved ones.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Jeffery C. Mays
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden observed the anniversary by encouraging Americans to defend the nation’s democratic system.

item.title: Here Are Some of the Photographs of 9/11
item.description: Photographers reflect on shooting the terrorist attacks of 9/11 and their aftermath.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Krista Niles/The New York Times

item.title: Museums in the U.S. and Europe Are in Blockbuster Mode
item.description: From Los Angeles to Antwerp, Jason Farago, our critic at large, picks a fall season laden with offerings on Cubism, modern Korean art and paintings of the Spanish Baroque.
item.dc:creator: Jason Farago
item.category: Los Angeles County Museum of Art
Cubism and the Trompe l'Oeil Tradition (Exhibit)

item.title: Fall Exhibitions That Widen the Beaten Path
item.description: Roberta Smith, co-chief art critic, on fall exhibitions that capture a period during which art and art history have been in flux, including the New Museum’s survey of the polymathic Theaster Gates.
item.dc:creator: Roberta Smith

item.title: Review: “Eliot After ‘The Waste Land,’” by Robert Crawford
item.description: “Eliot After ‘The Waste Land,’” the second volume of Robert Crawford’s two-part biography, offers some answers — and some revelations.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Epstein
item.category: Young Eliot: From St. Louis to 'The Waste Land' (Book)
item.media:credit: Hulton-Deutsch Collection/ via Getty Images
item.media:description: Trapped in an unhappy marriage, consumed with his own misery and anxiety, disgusted by modernity’s cultural disintegration, T.S. Eliot sought out stability and tradition wherever he could find them — chiefly in right-wing politics and the “ordering structure” of Christian faith.

item.title: Must We Discuss the Queen and the Donald in the Same Breath?
item.description: For one thing, the job of king is already taken.
item.dc:creator: Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
Hillbilly Elegy: A Memoir of a Family and Culture in Crisis (Book)
item.media:credit: Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images

item.title: The Future of Election Skepticism Is Arizona
item.description: If Mr. Trump’s endless refusal to concede has vastly expanded the universe of believers and skeptics, the sentiment has begun to detach from his personal fortunes.
item.dc:creator: Katherine Miller
item.media:credit: Mark Peterson for The New York Times

item.title: Enter the Candidate Wives
item.description: The Republican Party is under particular pressure to slap a friendly face on its nominees, with a special focus on wooing women.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Cottle
item.media:credit: Illustration by Leslie dela Vega/The New York Times, photographs by clockwise from top: Martha Asencio-Rhine/Tampa Bay Times, via Associated Press; John Lamparski/Getty Images; Tom R. Smedes/Associated Press; Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times; Gaelen Morse/Reuters

item.title: The Radical Constitutional Change Britain Needs
item.description: Might the Queen’s death lead to unstoppable pressure for radical constitutional change, even a new British constitution?
item.dc:creator: Linda Colley
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Dan Kitwood/Getty Images

item.title: Democrats’ Black Male Voter Problem
item.description: Stacey Abrams is concerned about Black male turnout in her race for governor in Georgia. She’s not the only Democrat who should be worried.
item.dc:creator: Charles M. Blow
item.media:credit: Anna Watts for The New York Times

item.title: The Killing of Eliza Fletcher Is a Tragedy, Not a Morality Play
item.description: She didn’t live and die to illustrate any point or serve a political agenda.
item.dc:creator: Margaret Renkl
item.media:credit: Mark Weber/Daily Memphian, via Associated Press

item.title: All Biden Has to Do Now Is Change the Way We Live
item.description: The president’s legacy — and our climate future — will turn on what actually gets built, and how fast.
item.dc:creator: Ezra Klein
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: A 2022 Ford F-150 Lightning Electric truck in production at the Dearborn Truck Plant in Michigan.

item.title: How to Argue Well
item.description: A former debating champion offers advice for our polarized moment.
item.dc:creator: Pamela Paul
item.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times; image by rasslava via Getty Images

item.title: The Sunday Read: ‘How the Claremont Institute Became a Nerve Center of the American Right’
item.description: It made the intellectual case for Trump. Now it believes the country is in a cultural civil war.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Zerofsky, Jack D’Isidoro, Elisheba Ittoop, John Woo, Dan Farrell and Quinton Kamara
item.media:credit: Photo illustration by Tyler Comrie

item.title: Why We Don’t Agree on High School Required Reading
item.description: Kaitlyn Greenidge and Esau McCaulley discuss why America’s schools can’t get on the same page about required reading lists.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Argument’
item.media:credit: Dmitry Marchenko/EyeEm, via Getty Images

item.title: Strong Women, Madwomen, Mob Women
item.description: Our critic recommends old and new books.
item.dc:creator: Molly Young

item.title: This Fish Has a Smart Shortcut
item.description: Kay Chun uses peanut butter to create a simple, savory glaze.
item.dc:creator: Emily Weinstein
item.media:credit: Christopher Testani for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Monica Pierini.

item.title: A Slain Reporter, a City of Sin and a Politician Charged With Murder
item.description: As journalism and Las Vegas changed, Jeff German stayed true to his style: Build sources, chase leads, and leave nobody safe from accountability.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Mike Baker
item.media:credit: Bridget Bennett for The New York Times
item.media:description: The killing of Jeff German, a reporter for The Las Vegas Review-Journal, has rattled and outraged the readers, journalists and sources who had grown to trust his brand of shoe leather reporting.

item.title: Diane Noomin, Who Helped Bring Feminism to Underground Comics, Dies at 75
item.description: Her best-known creation was a sendup of a certain kind of female stock character. But Ms. Noomin rendered her with compassion, and used her to tell important stories.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green

item.title: Aces Score Just Enough to Take W.N.B.A. Finals Lead
item.description: The Las Vegas Aces’ high-powered offense scored a season-low 67 points, but a double-double from A’ja Wilson, the league’s most valuable player, helped them outlast the Connecticut Sun.
item.dc:creator: Kris Rhim
item.media:credit: L.E. Baskow/Associated Press
item.media:description: A'ja Wilson, center, the league’s most valuable player, had a 24-point, 11-rebound double-double, as she faced last year's M.V.P., Jonquel Jones, left.

item.title: Can you get reinfected with monkeypox?
item.description: Experts weigh in on how long immunity lasts after an infection — or vaccination.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh
item.media:credit: Joe Raedle/Getty Images

item.title: Why Can’t I Stand the Sound of Chewing? Misophonia, Explained
item.description: Misophonia, a little-known syndrome, is characterized by strong negative emotional reactions to certain sounds or visual cues.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Guillem Casasús

item.title: We Want to Hear About Your Experience With Egg Freezing
item.description: The Times is looking for stories from readers.
item.media:credit: Jackie Molloy for The New York Times

item.title: The Power of a Casual Check-in Text
item.description: New research says most of us underestimate the power of the casual check-in.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson
item.category: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology
item.media:credit: Moritz Wienert

item.title: ‘Fall TV’ Is Dead. But Buzz Will Always Be With Us.
item.description: Two television critics ponder what fall TV even means in the streaming era and discuss the series they’re most looking forward to this season.
item.dc:creator: James Poniewozik and Margaret Lyons
item.category: Law & Order: Special Victims Unit (TV Program)
